descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From Chernobyl and Bhopal to Deep Water Horizon and Flint, Michigan toxicity looms as a persistent, uncertain, and often-intangible hazard throughout the world. The production and use of infrastructure, warfare, energy, agriculture, and everyday commodities present the potential for both massive chemical disasters as well as daily, long-term toxic exposure or what scholars refer to as "slow violence." This seminar examines the commodity chains, political controversies, fraught science, social movements, racial discrimination, and economic inequalities connected to the toxins we live with. Our ethnographic and historical case studies will cover diverse regions and contexts including: mining in Latin America and Indonesia, the Bhopal and Chernobyl disasters, nuclear energy and warfare, oil extraction and fracking, urban lead exposure in Michigan and Chicago, pesticides in the Caribbean, industrial runoff in Japan, work place exposures in the US and more.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Seminar-style (guided discussion).
PowerPoint usage minimal
Occasional film selections
Screen-free classroom unless permission previously granted

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
A course reader, including excerpts from the following books or similar articles. 1-2 of them may be chosen as case studies and read in their entirety:

Rachel Carson, "Silent Spring."
Adriana Petryna, "Life Exposed: Biological Citizens after Chernobyl."
Brett Walker, "Toxic Archipelago: A History of Industrial Disease in Japan."
Kate Brown, "Plutopia: Nuclear Families, Atomic Cities, and the Great Soviet and American Plutonium Disasters."
Joseph Masco, "The Nuclear Borderlands: The Manhattan Project in Post-Cold War New Mexico."
Michelle Murphy, "Sick Building Syndrome and the Problem of Uncertainty: Environmental Politics, Technoscience, and Women Workers."
Kim Fortun, "Advocacy after Bhopal: Environmentalism, Disaster, New Global Orders."
Gabrielle Hecht, "Being Nuclear: Africans and the Global Uranium Trade."
Fabiana Li, "Unearthing Conflict: Corporate Mining, Activism, and Expertise in Peru."
Melissa Checker, "Polluted Promises: Environmental Racism in a Southern Town."

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Course Requirements:
50-80 pages of reading per/week
Active participation in class
Weekly reading responses
Midterm paper (6-8 pages)
Final exam
